content.raw:
It doesn't *need* to, but I think blank is more appropriate than empty because it doesn't have the ground plane.

If someone is poking around trying to find out what the `SetVelocity` functions do (like I was), they might try placing the box initially at [0, 0, 0] (like I did) and get super confused with the results on the Z axis (like I did) unless they have someone who knows best around to explain that the box is hitting the ground plane (like how you helped me).

I know, it's a very specific situation... But if it can be avoided...
content.html:
It doesn't need to, but I think blank is more appropriate than empty because it doesn't have the ground plane.

If someone is poking around trying to find out what the SetVelocity functions do (like I was), they might try placing the box initially at [0, 0, 0] (like I did) and get super confused with the results on the Z axis (like I did) unless they have someone who knows best around to explain that the box is hitting the ground plane (like how you helped me).

I know, it's a very specific situation... But if it can be avoided...

pullrequest.title: Implemented AddLinkForce for ODE with integration tests

content.raw:
we could probably generalize this for multiple steps, it's a first order integrator, e.g.

~~~
acceleration = inv(MOI) * torque
v(n+1) = v(0) + dt * acceleration
~~~

loosely speaking.
content.html:
we could probably generalize this for multiple steps, it's a first order integrator, e.g.

acceleration = inv(MOI) * torque
v(n+1) = v(0) + dt * acceleration

loosely speaking.

pullrequest.title: Implemented AddLinkForce for ODE with integration tests

content.raw:
Some comments as an end user on the documentation related to this functions. 

I quote Wikipedia inline not because it is a reputable source, but because it is the standard place where 90 percent
of the users will check in case of doubt.  

 * `AddInertialForce` documentation refers to the "inertial frame", and I get from the context that is referring to the SDF inertial frame (because offset zero == COG ), but the traditional definition of the "inertial frame" is another [1] and it is in a sense more similar to the Gazebo "world frame". Perhaps an alternative name (but still possibly a lot confusing) can be "inertia frame", in the sense of the frame where the 3d inertia matrix is expressed? 

* The documentation repeatedly specify the input force vector is a "free vector", but the classical definition for "free vector" is a vector whose effect is independent from the point of application, such as a force couple. [2] In this case instead we are applying the specified vector to a point. 

[1] : http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inertial_frame_of_reference

[2] : http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Couple_%28mechanics%29
content.html:
Some comments as an end user on the documentation related to this functions.

I quote Wikipedia inline not because it is a reputable source, but because it is the standard place where 90 percent of the users will check in case of doubt.

  • AddInertialForce documentation refers to the "inertial frame", and I get from the context that is referring to the SDF inertial frame (because offset zero == COG ), but the traditional definition of the "inertial frame" is another [1] and it is in a sense more similar to the Gazebo "world frame". Perhaps an alternative name (but still possibly a lot confusing) can be "inertia frame", in the sense of the frame where the 3d inertia matrix is expressed?

  • The documentation repeatedly specify the input force vector is a "free vector", but the classical definition for "free vector" is a vector whose effect is independent from the point of application, such as a force couple. [2] In this case instead we are applying the specified vector to a point.

[1] : http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inertial_frame_of_reference

[2] : http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Couple_%28mechanics%29

pullrequest.title: Implemented AddLinkForce for ODE with integration tests

content.raw:
You make two very good points.

About "free vector",  I wanted to emphasize that "*When only the magnitude and direction of the vector matter, then the particular initial point is of no importance, the vector is called a free vector.*" [[1](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_vector#Overview)].  So while it can be rotated to other frames of reference, translating it would fundamentally change its "meaning". 

It is exactly what you said, "a vector whose effect is independent from the point of application". That's why we need the `_offset` argument in case we want to give it a point of application, because the `_force` vector itself won't carry this information. Does that make sense? If I'm not misunderstanding anything here, this seems to be the same that is said about the couples you mentioned, they are also free vectors.
content.html:
You make two very good points.

About "free vector", I wanted to emphasize that "When only the magnitude and direction of the vector matter, then the particular initial point is of no importance, the vector is called a free vector." [1]. So while it can be rotated to other frames of reference, translating it would fundamentally change its "meaning".

It is exactly what you said, "a vector whose effect is independent from the point of application". That's why we need the _offset argument in case we want to give it a point of application, because the _force vector itself won't carry this information. Does that make sense? If I'm not misunderstanding anything here, this seems to be the same that is said about the couples you mentioned, they are also free vectors.

pullrequest.title: Implemented AddLinkForce for ODE with integration tests

content.raw:
I don't know... I have the impression that the fact that you need an `_offset` argument to specify its point of application means that this vector is not a "free vector". 
Just to give a comparison, a function like `AddLinkCouple(const math::Vector3 &_couple)` would not need an `_offset` argument, because  it does not matter where do you apply the couple. 

Anyway unless we use a formal semantic definition for this terms  (as done in [1], for example) it is just a matter of taste, so I think it should not be a blocking issue. : )

[1] : http://scholar.google.com/scholar?cluster=9239106764752777506&hl=it&as_sdt=0,5&as_vis=1
content.html:
I don't know... I have the impression that the fact that you need an _offset argument to specify its point of application means that this vector is not a "free vector". Just to give a comparison, a function like AddLinkCouple(const math::Vector3 &_couple) would not need an _offset argument, because it does not matter where do you apply the couple.

Anyway unless we use a formal semantic definition for this terms (as done in [1], for example) it is just a matter of taste, so I think it should not be a blocking issue. : )

[1] : http://scholar.google.com/scholar?cluster=9239106764752777506&hl=it&as_sdt=0,5&as_vis=1
